channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Purdue Perl Mongers
item.description: December 11, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Toronto Perl Mongers monthly meeting
item.description: November 28, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Purdue Perl Mongers
item.description: November 13, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: Boston.pm monthly meeting
item.description: November 12, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week.

item.title: Largest Zuma
item.description: Rust seems the favourite programming language as it is the choosen one to solve the Zuma Game task. I must admit, you would need patience to follow through. Highly recommended.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #292
item.description: Nicely modularised solutions with enough documentation to get you to the bottom on task. Keep sharing the knowledge.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 292
item.description: Simple yet effective algorithm gets you the desired result. It is self explanatory. Thanks for the contribution.

item.title: Find the biggest and clear the balls
item.description: Breaking down big task into smaller sub tasks can be very handy. With DIY tool, you get to play with it too. Great work, thanks for sharing.

item.title: One Challenge, Twice Large
item.description: For music fans, we have powerful solutions with musical background. It is so much going through the technical details. Cool, keep it up.

item.title: Twice the Largest - Once the Zuma
item.description: Not just one but two different approaches discussed this week. It is very engaging for me. You must checkout too.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 292
item.description: Master of Perl one-liners didn't disappoint us this week as always. This is not to be missed for all Perl fans. Great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 292: Twice Largest
item.description: Raku never misses the opportunity to surprise me. Yet another gem from Laurent, brilliant work. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us every week.

item.title: Comes A Time
item.description: A very brave approach to solve the Zuma Game task using regex. The detailed discussion is really handy. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: The Largest Zuma
item.description: For all Raku fans, this is your chance to learn some more Raku magics. Highly recommended.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 292
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Twice Largest" and "Zuma Game" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 293
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Similar Dominos" and "Boomerang". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: What's new in Perl v5.40?
item.description: Please find the slides of my talk at LPW 2024. I hope you find it useful.

item.title: London Perl Workshop 2024
item.description: If you missed the talks by Dave then this is for you. It is worth bookmarking for later reading.

item.title: This week in PSC (165) | 2024-10-25
item.description: It was all about working on document about Perl version. Curious to know more about it.

item.title: #692 - LPW 2024: Quick Report
item.description:
Hi there,

The London Perl and Raku Conference 2024 finally happened last Saturday 26th October. It was a pleasant morning to start the day. I happened to arrive a bit early at the venue and met Paul Evans as he was going through the slides of his upcoming talks. It was nice to have a one-on-one conversation with him. For the first time in many years of attending LPW, I finally mustered the courage to break the ice.

Soon we all gathered in the main hall for the welcome presentation by Julien. I stayed in the same room for the most anticipated talk, Perl in 2030 by Paul Evans. As expected it was an engaging presentation about the future of Perl. This was followed by another interesting talk, Cloudy Perl, how it looks now by Dave Lambley. We took a break from technical talks for a quick presentation by Stuart Mackintosh who shared how TPRF is working towards the development of Perl and Raku. I had the honour of speaking to him afterward, thanking him for all the work TPRF is doing to bring the language back on track.

Unfortunately I missed the talk, Perl Diver by Dave Cross as it clashed with Paul Evans presentation. I am hoping to watch the video when it becomes available. I met so many friends after a long time, thanks to LPW 2024. I missed Neil Bowers and Lance Wicks very much but I was pleasantly surprised to meet Sawyer, Olaf Alders and Paul Cochrane. We spent quality time together.

After lunch, it was my turn present, What's new in Perl v5.40?. It was well attended, and Paul Evans made it even more special by sitting in the front row. I mostly stayed in the main hall for the rest of the talks and look forward to the recordings being available soon.

I had planned to attend the post workshop social but decided to skip it at the last minute as I wasn't feeling well. I am sure those who attended had a great time. I hope to see you all again around this time next year.

Last but not least I would like to encourage you to submit your proposal for the Perl Advent Calendar 2024. You can find more information here.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter and please take extra care of yourself.
item.dc:subject: editorial
